items.title: Quantitative Rule-Based Strategy modeling in Classic Indian Rummy: A Metric Optimization Approach
items.authors: Purushottam Saha, Avirup Chakraborty, Sourish Sarkar, Subhamoy Maitra, Diganta Mukherjee, Tridib Mukherjee
items.contributions: 1. Proposed a new hand-evaluation metric called MinDist, which quantifies the edit distance to a valid hand, improving upon the MinScore metric. 2. Designed a computationally efficient algorithm to calculate MinDist using dynamic pruning and pattern caching. 3. Integrated opponent hand-modeling within a two-player zero-sum simulation framework and validated the strategy's superiority through statistical hypothesis testing.
items.summary: This paper proposes a rule-based strategy for Classic Indian Rummy using a new hand-evaluation metric called MinDist, which measures the structural proximity to a winning hand. The method includes an efficient algorithm to compute MinDist and incorporates opponent modeling in simulations. Empirical results show that agents using this strategy achieve significantly higher win rates compared to traditional heuristic-based agents.

items.title: Sparse Probabilistic Coalition Structure Generation: Bayesian Greedy Pursuit and $_1$ Relaxations
items.authors: Angshul Majumdar
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel probabilistic framework for Coalition Structure Generation (CSG) where coalition values are learned from episodic observations via sparse linear regression. 2. Introduces and analyzes the Bayesian Greedy Coalition Pursuit (BGCP) algorithm, providing theoretical guarantees for exact coalition recovery under certain conditions. 3. Provides theoretical analysis for an alternative ℓ1-penalized estimation scheme, deriving error bounds and translating them into welfare gap guarantees, and compares regimes where sparse methods outperform classical approaches.
items.summary: This paper addresses coalition structure generation when coalition values are unknown and must be learned from noisy episodic data. It proposes a sparse probabilistic framework with two estimation methods: a Bayesian greedy pursuit algorithm and an ℓ1-penalized estimator, providing theoretical recovery and error guarantees. The analysis identifies conditions under which these sparse learning approaches yield welfare-optimal structures and outperform classical methods.

items.title: Unifying Proportional Fairness in Centroid and Non-Centroid Clustering
items.authors: Benjamin Cookson, Nisarg Shah, Ziqi Yu
items.contributions: 1. Introduces a novel "semi-centroid clustering" paradigm that generalizes both centroid and non-centroid clustering by combining their loss functions. 2. Proposes a novel polynomial-time algorithm that achieves a constant-factor approximation to the strong "core" fairness criterion, even when different distance metrics are used for centroid and non-centroid losses. 3. Derives improved results and lower bounds for more restricted loss functions and the weaker "fully justified representation (FJR)" fairness criterion.
items.summary: This paper unifies two fairness paradigms in clustering by proposing a generalized "semi-centroid clustering" model where a point's loss is a combination of its distance to a centroid and its maximum distance to other points in its cluster. The authors develop a novel polynomial-time algorithm that provides a constant approximation guarantee for the strong "core" fairness criterion. This work bridges prior research on centroid and non-centroid clustering under proportional fairness.

items.title: The CoinAlg Bind: Profitability-Fairness Tradeoffs in Collective Investment Algorithms
items.authors: Andrés Fábrega, James Austgen, Samuel Breckenridge, Jay Yu, Amy Zhao, Sarah Allen, Aditya Saraf, Ari Juels
items.institution: Cornell Tech, IC3, Pantera Capital, Ava Labs, Flashbots
items.contributions: 1. Formally defines the "CoinAlg Bind," a fundamental tradeoff where collective investment algorithms cannot simultaneously ensure economic fairness and avoid profit loss to arbitrage. 2. Presents a formal model of CoinAlgs with definitions of privacy and economic fairness, proving that privacy enables insider attacks while transparency enables arbitrage. 3. Empirically validates both sides of the tradeoff using data from the Uniswap decentralized exchange, quantifying arbitrage impact and demonstrating risks from covert-channel leaks.
items.summary: This paper identifies a fundamental tradeoff in Collective Investment Algorithms (CoinAlgs), called the CoinAlg Bind, where algorithms must choose between privacy (risking unfair insider value extraction) and transparency (risking profit erosion from arbitrage). The authors present a formal model and game-theoretic proofs to demonstrate this bind and empirically validate it using data from Uniswap. The main conclusion is that CoinAlgs inherently cannot guarantee both economic fairness and full profitability.

items.title: Bayesian Inverse Games with High-Dimensional Multi-Modal Observations
items.authors: Yash Jain, Xinjie Liu, Lasse Peters, David Fridovich-Keil, Ufuk Topcu
items.institution: The University of Texas at Austin, Delft University of Technology
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a Bayesian inference framework for inverse games to quantify uncertainty in estimating agent objectives, addressing the overconfidence of point-estimate methods. 2. Introduces a structured variational autoencoder with an embedded differentiable Nash game solver, enabling posterior sampling without requiring labeled objective data. 3. Demonstrates that multimodal inference reduces uncertainty when trajectory data is insufficient, leading to safer downstream planning decisions.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of inferring agents' hidden objectives in multi-agent interactions, where existing maximum likelihood methods produce overconfident point estimates. The authors propose a Bayesian inverse game framework using a structured variational autoencoder with a differentiable Nash solver to generate posterior samples from multimodal observations. Experiments show the method improves inference quality, quantifies uncertainty, and enables safer autonomous decision-making compared to prior approaches.

items.title: Personalized Promotions in Practice: Dynamic Allocation and Reference Effects
items.authors: Jackie Baek, Will Ma, Dmitry Mitrofanov
items.institution: New York University, Columbia University, Boston College
items.contributions: 1. An efficient, deployed policy for daily personalized promotions to over 20 million customers under global constraints. 2. A novel combinatorial model of pricing with reference effects, where a customer's purchase likelihood depends on the best promotion seen over a past window. 3. A theoretical characterization proving optimal policies cycle between poor and good promotion values to maximize long-run revenue.
items.summary: The paper addresses the practical problem of sending daily personalized discounts to a massive customer base for a large online retailer. It proposes and deploys an efficient dynamic allocation policy, which increased revenue by 4.5% in an A/B test, and introduces a theoretical model of customer reference effects that leads to optimal cyclic promotion strategies.

items.title: Multilevel Fair Allocation
items.authors: Maxime Lucet, Nawal Benabbou, Aurélie Beynier, Nicolas Maudet
items.contributions: 1. Introduces the novel concept of multilevel fair allocation for hierarchical agent structures, 2. Proposes a generic polynomial-time sequential algorithm with theoretical fairness/efficiency guarantees, 3. Extends the General Yankee Swap algorithm to the multilevel setting with efficiency guarantees and demonstrated practical fairness.
items.summary: This paper introduces the problem of multilevel fair allocation, where resources are distributed among agents organized in a tree hierarchy. It proposes two algorithms: a generic top-down sequential algorithm with theoretical guarantees and an extension of the General Yankee Swap algorithm for the multilevel setting. The work provides both theoretical and practical solutions for achieving fairness and efficiency in hierarchical resource allocation.

items.title: On the Difficulty of Measuring Divisiveness of Proposals under Ranked Preferences
items.authors: Ulle Endriss
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a formal model for analyzing the divisiveness of proposals based on user-reported preferences in digital democracy platforms. 2. Explores and provides clear definitions for selecting the most divisive proposals from a set of ranked preferences. 3. Uses the axiomatic method to demonstrate fundamental difficulties and impossibility results in selecting divisive proposals while satisfying mild normative requirements.
items.summary: This paper investigates how to measure the divisiveness of policy proposals based on people's ranked preferences, a task relevant for digital democracy platforms. It proposes formal definitions for selecting divisive proposals and applies an axiomatic analysis from social choice theory. The main conclusion is that this task faces fundamental difficulties, as it is impossible to satisfy seemingly basic normative requirements simultaneously.

items.title: BEDA: Belief Estimation as Probabilistic Constraints for Performing Strategic Dialogue Acts
items.authors: Hengli Li, Zhaoxin Yu, Qi Shen, Chenxi Li, Mengmeng Wang, Tinglang Wu, Yipeng Kang, Yuxuan Wang, Song-Chun Zhu, Zixia Jia, Zilong Zheng
items.institution: Peking University (PKU), Beijing Institute for General Artificial Intelligence (BIGAI), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications (BUPT), Tsinghua University (THU)
items.contributions: 1. Formalizes two core strategic dialogue acts (Adversarial and Alignment) within a game-theoretic framework of beliefs and common knowledge. 2. Proposes a principled mechanism that operationalizes these acts by casting belief estimation as probabilistic constraints on utterance generation. 3. Introduces the BEDA framework, which integrates a world set, a belief estimator, and a conditional generator to select acts and realize utterances consistent with inferred beliefs.
items.summary: The paper addresses the gap between accurate belief estimation and its principled use in strategic dialogue generation. It proposes BEDA, a framework that formalizes adversarial and alignment dialogue acts and uses belief estimates as probabilistic constraints to guide utterance generation. The method consistently outperforms strong baselines across adversarial, cooperative, and negotiation settings, demonstrating its effectiveness.

items.title: Automated Market Making for Energy Sharing
items.authors: Michele Fabi, Viraj Nadkarni, Leonardo Leone, Matheus X.V. Ferreira
items.institution: Telecom Paris (IP Paris), Princeton University, University of Virginia
items.contributions: 1. Developed an axiomatic theory for Automated Market Makers (AMMs) in local energy sharing markets, identifying a class of mechanisms with specific properties. 2. Proved that implementing batch execution and concentrated liquidity allows the construction of AMMs that satisfy the axioms, ensuring budget balance and ex-ante efficiency. 3. Solved the equilibrium of the resulting economy by modeling it as a Potential Game and decentralizing the social planner's optimum, demonstrating significant gains from trade in numerical experiments.
items.summary: This paper proposes using Automated Market Makers (AMMs) for local energy sharing among prosumers. The method formulates the problem as a Mean-Field Game, designs AMMs based on specific axioms and decentralized finance principles, and solves for equilibrium. The results show the approach can achieve up to 40% gains from trade compared to relying solely on the grid.

items.title: Analyzing Skill Element in Online Fantasy Cricket
items.authors: Sarthak Sarkar, Supratim Das, Purushottam Saha, Diganta Mukherjee, Tridib Mukherjee
items.contributions: 1. Development of a statistical framework to assess the role of skill in online fantasy cricket. 2. Construction and analysis of a range of deterministic and stochastic team selection strategies. 3. Introduction of a dynamic tournament model with agent populations evolving via a softmax reweighting mechanism.
items.summary: This paper develops a statistical framework to analyze whether success in online fantasy cricket is driven by skill or chance. It constructs various team selection strategies and a dynamic tournament model, testing them on IPL 2024 data. The results provide quantitative evidence supporting the presence of a skill element in these platforms.

items.title: Beyond Exact Fairness: Envy-Free Incomplete Connected Fair Division
items.authors: Ajaykrishnan E S, Daniel Lokshtanov
items.contributions: Proved the computational hardness of the Envy-Free Incomplete Connected Fair Division problem even on star graphs with unary input, resolving an open problem., Designed an Efficient Parameterized Approximation Scheme for the problem when allowing a small amount of envy, parameterized by p and the number of agent types., Showed the algorithm works on general graphs and remains efficient even with binary input representation.
items.summary: This paper studies the Envy-Free Incomplete Connected Fair Division problem, where p graph vertices must be allocated to agents with connected, envy-free shares. It proves the problem is computationally hard for exact fairness but becomes efficiently solvable with a parameterized approximation scheme when slight envy is tolerated.

items.title: Computing Pure-Strategy Nash Equilibria in a Two-Party Policy Competition: Existence and Algorithmic Approaches
items.authors: Chuang-Chieh Lin, Chi-Jen Lu, Po-An Chen, Chih-Chieh Hung
items.institution: National Taiwan Ocean University, Academia Sinica, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, National Chung Hsing University
items.contributions: 1. Formulated a two-party policy competition game and validated the isotonicity hypothesis of winning probability through simulations. 2. Proved the existence of a pure-strategy Nash equilibrium (PSNE) in both one- and multi-dimensional policy spaces. 3. Proposed and experimentally validated a decentralized gradient-based algorithm and a polynomial-time grid-based search algorithm for finding approximate PSNEs.
items.summary: This paper models two-party policy competition as a continuous non-cooperative game where parties choose policy vectors and a party's payoff is the expected utility for its supporters. The authors prove the existence of a pure-strategy Nash equilibrium and propose two algorithms—a gradient-based method and a grid-based search—that efficiently find approximate equilibria.

items.title: Cyber Resilience in Next-Generation Networks: Threat Landscape, Theoretical Foundations, and Design Paradigms
items.authors: Junaid Farooq, Quanyan Zhu
items.institution: University of Michigan-Dearborn, New York University
items.contributions: 1. Provides an interdisciplinary survey and analysis of the evolving threat landscape for next-generation networks, including AI-driven threats. 2. Establishes rigorous definitions and evaluation frameworks for cyber resilience that extend beyond traditional robustness and fault-tolerance. 3. Delves into advanced design paradigms and practical strategies, such as zero trust architectures and AI-enabled autonomous network control, for building resilient systems.
items.summary: This book examines the challenge of achieving cyber resilience in next-generation networks, which are characterized by technologies like SDN and NFV. It proposes a re-conceptualized framework for resilience and explores advanced design paradigms, including AI-driven methods, to enable adaptive and autonomous threat response. The main conclusion is that a fundamental redesign of resilience mechanisms is required to secure the evolving, heterogeneous network infrastructure.

items.title: Reach-Avoid Differential game with Reachability Analysis for UAVs: A decomposition approach
items.authors: Minh Bui, Simon Monckton, Mo Chen
items.institution: Simon Fraser University, Defense Research & Development Canada (DRDC)
items.contributions: 1. A novel dimensionality reduction framework for 3D reach-avoid games by decomposing the problem into horizontal and vertical sub-games., 2. A Hamilton-Jacobi-based tracking control algorithm to reconstruct the solution from sub-games, guaranteeing capture and subsequent tracking of the attacker., 3. Theoretical proof of the conditions for maintaining capture guarantees and empirical validation in both numerical simulations and a physics simulator (Gazebo).
items.summary: This paper tackles the high-dimensional challenge of 3D reach-avoid differential games for UAVs by proposing a decomposition approach that splits the problem into horizontal and vertical sub-games, solves them using Hamilton-Jacobi reachability analysis, and uses a novel tracking control to reconstruct the solution. The method is proven to maintain optimality and capture guarantees, and its effectiveness is successfully demonstrated through simulations and a physics simulator for quadrotor capture.

items.title: Facility Location Games for Multi-Location Agents with Satisfaction
items.authors: Huanjun Wang, Qizhi Fang, Wenjing Liu
items.contributions: 1. Proposed group strategy-proof mechanisms for desirable facility location games with approximation ratios of 2 and 5/4 for sum and max-variant satisfaction objectives, respectively. 2. Established optimal deterministic mechanisms for obnoxious facility games with approximation ratio 2 and devised 4/3-approximation randomized mechanisms. 3. Provided lower bounds for randomized strategy-proof mechanisms in obnoxious settings, showing limits of 1.0625 and 1.0448 for sum and max-variant satisfaction.
items.summary: This paper studies mechanism design for single-facility location games where agents have multiple private locations and satisfaction-based objectives. It proposes deterministic and randomized group strategy-proof mechanisms for both desirable and obnoxious facility settings, achieving bounded approximation ratios for maximizing sum or minimum of satisfactions, and establishes lower bounds showing some mechanisms are optimal.

items.title: Impact of Volatility on Time-Based Transaction Ordering Policies
items.authors: Sunghun Ko, Jinsuk Park
items.institution: Matroos Labs, KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a single-round economic model for the Express Lane Auction (ELA) that incorporates risk-averse bidders and the difficulty of forecasting short-term volatility. 2. Derives the hypothesis that the value of priority access is discounted relative to a risk-neutral valuation due to these factors. 3. Empirically tests the model's predictions using real-world ELA bid data matched with high-frequency ETH price data, finding consistency with the theoretical model.
items.summary: This paper studies Arbitrum's Express Lane Auction (ELA), a mechanism for prioritizing blockchain transactions. The authors build an economic model suggesting bidders discount the value of priority access due to risk aversion and volatility forecasting challenges, and their empirical analysis of real bid data supports this hypothesis.

items.title: Why AI Safety Requires Uncertainty, Incomplete Preferences, and Non-Archimedean Utilities
items.authors: Alessio Benavoli, Alessandro Facchini, Marco Zaffalon
items.institution: Trinity College Dublin, SUPSI (University of Applied Sciences and Arts of Southern Switzerland), Kozminski University
items.contributions: 1. Formally connects the AI assistance and AI shutdown problems to the need for reasoning under uncertainty. 2. Argues that handling incomplete human preferences is a fundamental requirement for safe AI. 3. Proposes that non-Archimedean utility structures are necessary to correctly model and prioritize safety constraints.
items.summary: This paper analyzes AI safety through the frameworks of the AI assistance and AI shutdown games. It argues that to address these challenges, AI agents must be designed to reason under uncertainty and handle incomplete and non-Archimedean human preferences. The main conclusion is that these capabilities are essential for ensuring AI systems remain aligned with human values and safe.

items.title: Verifiable Off-Chain Governance
items.authors: Jake Hartnell, Eugenio, Battaglia
items.contributions: 1. A formal model for attestation-based governance that computes multi-dimensional stakeholder legitimacy from verifiable social graphs. 2. Collective intelligence mechanisms that process community preferences through verifiable, auditable pipelines. 3. Autonomous policy execution via Policy-as-Code for adaptive governance.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of primitive, token-weighted voting in DAOs caused by on-chain computational limits. It proposes a framework using verifiable off-chain computation (Verifiable Services, TEEs, ZK proofs) to enable more expressive and efficient governance mechanisms. The conclusion is that this framework provides a practical path for DAOs to achieve higher-resolution governance, validated by pioneering implementations.

items.title: NashOpt - A Python Library for Computing Generalized Nash Equilibria
items.authors: Alberto Bemporad
items.institution: IMT School for Advanced Studies Lucca
items.contributions: 1. An open-source Python library (NashOpt) for computing Generalized Nash Equilibria (GNEs) in games with shared constraints. 2. A unified framework solving nonlinear GNEs via nonlinear least-squares (using JAX) and linear-quadratic GNEs via mixed-integer linear programming. 3. Extension of the framework to support inverse-game and Stackelberg game-design problems.
items.summary: The paper introduces NashOpt, a Python library for computing Generalized Nash Equilibria in noncooperative games. It solves nonlinear games using a least-squares approach with JAX and linear-quadratic games via mixed-integer programming, also supporting game-design problems. The library's capabilities are demonstrated on control problems like linear quadratic regulation and model predictive control.

items.authors: Youichiro Higashi, Kemal Ozbek, Norio Takeoka
items.institution: Okayama University, University of Southampton, Hitotsubashi University
items.contributions: 1. Proposes novel axiomatic foundations for Bayesian persuasion models where the principal can manage the agent's bias. 2. Introduces an elicitation method to construct the principal's subjective information acquisition costs using only observable menu-choice data. 3. Characterizes models where costly information acquisition is combined with the anticipation of steering the agent's bias.
items.summary: This paper studies the axiomatic foundations of Bayesian persuasion, where a principal informs a biased agent. It proposes new models where the principal can steer the agent's bias after acquiring costly information and provides a method to elicit the principal's subjective information costs from observable choice data.

items.title: Dynamic Cooperative Strategies in Search Engine Advertising Market: With and Without Retail Competition
items.authors: Huiran Li, Qiucheng Li, Baozhu Feng
items.institution: Shanghai Customs College, Anhui University of Finance and Economics
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel dynamic cooperative advertising optimization model for the SEA market that incorporates direct manufacturer advertising and retailer subsidies. 2. Analyzes two distinct scenarios (with and without retail competition) and provides feasible equilibrium solutions for optimal policies. 3. Investigates the impact of key factors like dynamic quality scores, gross margin, and competitor market share through numerical experiments and sensitivity analysis.
items.summary: This paper models cooperative advertising strategies in the search engine advertising (SEA) market using a differential game framework over a finite time horizon. It proposes an optimization model where a manufacturer can advertise directly and subsidize a retailer, analyzing scenarios with and without a competing independent retailer. The study provides equilibrium solutions and numerical insights, concluding that retail competition significantly impacts the optimal cooperative strategy and overall channel performance.

items.title: EFX Allocations Exist on Triangle-Free Multi-Graphs
items.authors: Mahyar Afshinmehr, Arash Ashuri, Pouria Mahmoudkhan, Kurt Mehlhorn
items.institution: Sharif University of Technology, Max Planck Institute for Informatics
items.contributions: 1. Proved the existence of EFX allocations for multi-graph valuations on triangle-free graphs, strengthening previous results. 2. Provided a pseudo-polynomial time algorithm to compute such allocations under monotone valuations. 3. Showed the algorithm runs in polynomial time for the broader class of cancelable valuations.
items.summary: This paper studies the fair allocation of indivisible goods to ensure envy-freeness up to any good (EFX). It proves that EFX allocations always exist when goods are represented as edges on a triangle-free multi-graph, and provides a computational algorithm for finding them. This result significantly expands the known conditions under which EFX allocations are guaranteed to exist for any number of agents.

items.title: Near-Optimal Coalition Structures in Polynomial Time
items.authors: Angshul Majumdar
items.institution: Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology, Delhi
items.contributions: 1. Proves that under a "sparse synergy" model, sparse relaxation methods can find near-optimal coalition structures in polynomial time with high probability. 2. Demonstrates that broad classes of dynamic programming and MILP algorithms require exponential time to achieve comparable solution quality. 3. Establishes a rigorous probabilistic anytime performance separation favoring sparse relaxations over exact methods for the CSG problem.
items.summary: This paper studies the coalition structure generation (CSG) problem. It compares three algorithmic paradigms and proves that, under a random sparse synergy model, sparse relaxation methods can find near-optimal solutions in polynomial time, while exact methods like DP and MILP require exponential time to reach similar quality, establishing a clear anytime performance advantage for the sparse approach.

items.title: Multi-agent Adaptive Mechanism Design
items.authors: Qiushi Han, David Simchi-Levi, Renfei Tan, Zishuo Zhao
items.institution: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign
items.contributions: 1. Introduces DRAM, a novel framework combining mechanism design and online learning to handle unknown agent beliefs. 2. Provides theoretical guarantees of high-probability truthfulness and achieves optimal $\tilde\{O\}(\sqrt\{T\})$ cumulative regret with a matching lower bound. 3. Generalizes the framework (DRAM+) to support plug-in estimators, structured priors, and delayed feedback.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of designing a truthful mechanism when the principal has no prior knowledge of agents' beliefs. It proposes the Distributionally Robust Adaptive Mechanism (DRAM), which iteratively learns beliefs and updates a robust optimization problem to minimize cost while ensuring truthfulness. The mechanism is proven to achieve optimal regret, and the framework is the first to maintain truthfulness under these general learning conditions.

items.title: Determining Blockchain Transaction Timing and Fee with Observable Mempools
items.authors: Qianlan Bai, Yuedong Xu, Zhijian Zhou, Xin Wang
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel transaction policy for a strategic user that jointly optimizes transaction broadcasting time and fee, considering observable mempools. 2. Derives optimal strategies for two user scenarios: mempool-oblivious users (with arbitrary mining interval distributions) and semi-strategic users (with Poisson fee updates). 3. Formulates a continuous-time Markov chain to model mempool dynamics and derives the optimal fee adjustment frequency for the strategic user.
items.summary: This paper investigates how a strategic user can optimize transaction broadcasting time and fee in blockchain systems with observable mempools and fee bumping. It analyzes optimal strategies under different user behavior models and block generation distributions (exponential for PoW, fixed for PoS). The key finding is that the strategic user should immediately increase the fee when it falls below the inclusion threshold.

Aims to maximize Nash social welfare while satisfying incentive compatibility, individual rationality, and practical business constraints, despite theoretical impossibility. 3. Demonstrates superiority over classical VCG and other baseline mechanisms in a realistic perishable goods setting.

The mechanism aims to maximize Nash social welfare while approximately satisfying key economic properties. The results show it outperforms traditional mechanisms like VCG in this practical setting.

items.authors: Federico Bobbio, Randall A. Berry, Michael L. Honig, Thanh Nguyen, Vijay G. Subramanian, Rakesh V. Vohra
items.institution: Northwestern University, Purdue University, University of Michigan, University of Pennsylvania
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel mechanism design formulation for resource allocation with private information and without direct monetary transfers. 2. Characterizes the optimal mechanism for this problem setting. 3. Describes the qualitative properties of the derived optimal mechanism.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of efficiently allocating a shared resource, like radio spectrum, between non-commercial incumbents and commercial users when direct monetary transfers are infeasible and both parties hold private information. The authors propose a new mechanism design framework that incorporates costly inspections to verify claims. They characterize the optimal mechanism and describe its key properties for achieving efficient allocation under these constraints.

items.title: Centralization and Stability in Formal Constitutions
items.authors: Yotam Gafni
items.contributions: 1. Introduces the formal concept of a "self-maintaining" Social Choice Function (SCF), which is stable against being replaced by another SCF through its own voting process. 2. Proves a dynamic impossibility theorem (an "Arrow-Style" Theorem for Dynamics) showing that under i.i.d. unbiased beliefs, only dictatorships are self-maintaining. 3. Models the wisdom of the crowd effect to show how the stable size of a ruling elite decreases with economic extractiveness and improves in individual decision quality.
items.summary: This paper studies the stability of voting rules (Social Choice Functions) in formal systems like DAOs, where the rules themselves can be voted on. It introduces the concept of a "self-maintaining" SCF and analyzes its implications for centralization. The main findings are that, under certain conditions, only dictatorial rules are stable, and the stable size of a ruling elite shrinks with a more extractive economy or better individual decision-making.

items.title: Mechanism-Based Intelligence (MBI): Differentiable Incentives for Rational Coordination and Guaranteed Alignment in Multi-Agent Systems
items.authors: Stefano Grassi
items.institution: None (No affiliation or email domain provided in the given content)
items.contributions: 1. Proposes Mechanism-Based Intelligence (MBI), a new paradigm framing intelligence as emergent from the coordination of multiple agents. 2. Introduces the Differentiable Price Mechanism (DPM), which computes exact loss gradients as incentive signals to guarantee Dominant Strategy Incentive Compatibility and convergence. 3. Demonstrates a framework that scales linearly with the number of agents, bypassing Dec-POMDP complexity and showing significant empirical speedup over model-free RL.
items.summary: The paper addresses the fragility of multi-agent systems in coordinating private information and aligning incentives. It proposes Mechanism-Based Intelligence (MBI) and its core Differentiable Price Mechanism (DPM), which uses differentiable incentives to align agent actions with global objectives. The method guarantees incentive compatibility, scales efficiently, and is shown to be much faster than standard reinforcement learning approaches.

items.title: (Im)possibility of Incentive Design for Challenge-based Blockchain Protocols
items.authors: Suhyeon Lee, Dieu-Huyen Nguyen, Donghwan Lee
items.contributions: 1. A formal model for analyzing incentive design in challenge-based blockchain protocols, incorporating a colluding minority, heterogeneous costs, and three ordering modes. 2. A theoretical impossibility or limitation result for achieving honest non-loss and fraud deterrence in single-winner challenge protocol designs. 3. A positive result showing that multi-winner designs can achieve both goals under simple, explicit conditions.
items.summary: This paper investigates whether challenge-based blockchain protocols (like optimistic rollups) can properly incentivize honest challengers and punish dishonest proposers. By building a formal model, the authors find that single-winner designs cannot reliably achieve these goals, but multi-winner designs can under specific conditions.

items.title: Policy-Conditioned Policies for Multi-Agent Task Solving
items.authors: Yue Lin, Shuhui Zhu, Wenhao Li, Ang Li, Dan Qiao, Pascal Poupart, Hongyuan Zha, Baoxiang Wang
items.institution: The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen; University of Waterloo; Tongji University; Vector Institute
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a paradigm shift by representing agent policies as human-interpretable source code, bridging the gap between opaque neural policies and the need for strategy comprehension in multi-agent settings. 2. Introduces Programmatic Iterated Best Response (PIBR), a novel algorithm that uses LLMs as point-wise best-response operators to synthesize and refine policy code based on game utility and unit tests. 3. Operationalizes the game-theoretic concept of Program Equilibrium for modern learning, demonstrating its effectiveness on coordination games and a cooperative foraging environment.
items.summary: This paper addresses the challenge of dynamic strategy adaptation in multi-agent tasks by representing policies as interpretable source code and using Large Language Models (LLMs) to optimize them. The core method, Programmatic Iterated Best Response (PIBR), leverages LLMs to iteratively refine an agent's policy code in response to an opponent's strategy using textual feedback. The approach successfully solves standard coordination games and a cooperative environment, demonstrating a practical bridge between theoretical Program Equilibrium and modern AI learning.

items.authors: Mélissa Tamine, Otmane Sakhi, Benjamin Heymann
items.institution: Criteo AI Lab, Fairplay joint team
items.summary: This paper proposes an efficient method for computing Shapley values to value data contributions for LLM fine-tuning. It leverages the specific mathematical structure of Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) to enable scalable Shapley value approximation without requiring numerous model retrainings. The main conclusion is that this approach dramatically simplifies the computational challenge of data valuation for LLMs, unlocking applications in data markets and collaborative training.

items.title: Ev-Trust: A Strategy Equilibrium Trust Mechanism for Evolutionary Games in LLM-Based Multi-Agent Services
items.authors: Shiduo Yang, Jiye Wang, Jiayu Qin, Jianbin Li, Yu Wang, Yuanhe Zhao, Kenan Guo
items.institution: State Grid Corporation of China, North China Electric Power University
items.summary: The paper proposes Ev-Trust, a trust mechanism based on evolutionary game theory that integrates direct trust, indirect trust, and expected revenue to guide agent behavior in LLM-based multi-agent systems. Theoretical analysis proves the stability of evolutionary equilibria, and experiments show the approach reduces malicious strategies and increases collective revenue in open service interactions.

items.title: Stackelberg Learning from Human Feedback: Preference Optimization as a Sequential Game
items.authors: Barna Pásztor, Thomas Kleine Buening, Andreas Krause
items.summary: This paper introduces Stackelberg Learning from Human Feedback (SLHF), a new framework that frames preference optimization as a sequential-move game between a Leader and a Follower policy. It demonstrates that this approach offers advantages in consistency, data sensitivity, and robustness to intransitive preferences compared to RLHF and NLHF. Experiments on large language models show that SLHF achieves strong alignment and enables inference-time refinements that transfer across model families.

items.authors: Daniel A. Herrmann, Abinav Chari, Isabelle Qian, Sree Sharvesh, B. A. Levinstein
items.institution: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Georgia Institute of Technology, University of California, Berkeley, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
items.summary: This paper introduces a formal, decision-theoretic framework to analyze when to delegate decisions to an AI agent by balancing its value alignment, epistemic accuracy, and reach. It concludes that universal delegation requires near-perfect alignment, but context-specific delegation can be optimal even with significant misalignment if the agent's superior accuracy or expanded reach offers a net benefit.
